message_1: In a data set of 50 values, the mean value is 25 and the standard deviation is 5. Find the number of values that fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean.
message_2:
To find the number of values that fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean, we need to determine the range of values that are within 2 standard deviations.

Mean (μ) = 25
Standard Deviation (σ) = 5

Lower limit = μ - 2σ = 25 - 2(5) = 25 - 10 = 15
Upper limit = μ + 2σ = 25 + 2(5) = 25 + 10 = 35

So, the range of values within 2 standard deviations of the mean is 15 to 35.

Now, we need to find the number of values in the data set that fall within this range. Since we don't have the actual data set, we can only determine the percentage of values that should fall within this range based on the empirical rule (also known as the 68-95-99.7 rule) for normal distributions.

The empirical rule states that approximately 95% of the values in a normal distribution fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean. Since there are 50 values in the data set, we can calculate the number of values within 2 standard deviations as follows:

Number of values within 2 standard deviations = 0.95 * 50 = 47.5

Since we can't have a fraction of a value, we can round this number to the nearest whole number. In this case, we'll round up to 48.

Therefore, approximately 48 values in the data set fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean.
